awd_titl_txt: Effect of hydrodynamic interactions on electrochemical performance of flowable electrodes
awd_abstract_narration:
A new type of electrode called a "flowable electrode" has been used in several emerging energy- and environment-related technologies, such as the electrochemical flow capacitor for storing electrical energy and capacitive deionization for treating brackish water.  During the operation of a flowable electrode, a slurry of small, highly porous carbon beads mixed with an aqueous electrolyte flows into an electrochemical cell and is charged with an applied voltage. Ions are adsorbed to the interior surface of the carbon beads through their pores to store electrical charge.  Because the porous carbon beads have enormous interior surface area relative to their mass, they can store or release a tremendous amount of ions and electrons in a very short time.  This process allows more rapid charging and discharging compared with conventional rechargeable batteries.  The flow capacitor has the potential to achieve 100 times faster charging and 1000 times longer lifetime than Li-ion batteries. Furthermore, the flow architecture makes it scalable for grid energy storage.  Achieving these potentials requires detailed knowledge about how the detailed configuration of the slurry affects electrical conductivity and charging.  The electrical network within the slurry consists of carbon particles in intermittent contact causing electrical pathways to be rapidly disrupted and reformed.  Thus, the entire slurry displays unique behavior in electrical conductivity and charging characteristics, which are key to the performance of the flowable electrode.  This project will investigate how hydrodynamic interactions at the carbon particle level affects the critical properties of flowable electrodes.  The results will help improve efficiency of flow electrodes, which will contribute to sustainable developments in energy and water resources.  The interdisciplinary nature of the project provides rich opportunities for students from high-school to graduate levels to participate in the research.

This project combines experimental and computational approaches to explore the hydrodynamic interactions of activated carbon particles with diameters from 1 to 10 micrometers, and the electrochemical processes of flowable electrodes.  Novel microfluidic devices will be constructed to directly observe particle interactions and, simultaneously, to measure the electrical or electrochemical properties of the slurry.  Dielectric-rheo setups will be used to measure properties at the macroscopic level.  The computational efforts will employ a new numerical model to simulate the micro-hydrodynamics of the particles, the topology-varying electrical circuit of the particle network, and their coupling.  The experimental data will provide critical parameters such as the electrical resistance and capacitance of the particle network to the computational model.  The computational model will extract effects of shear rate and particle concentration on the particle cluster characteristics, including cluster sizes, lengths, and orientations, and their effects on the anisotropic conductivity and transient charging behavior of the flowable electrode.  The studies will produce knowledge to improve the  performance of flowable electrodes in energy and environment technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The slurry of porous carbon particles mixed with an aqueous electrolyte has been used in emerging electrochemical systems as "flowable electrodes", e.g., the electrochemical flow capacitor (EFC) for energy storage and flow-electrode capacitive deionization (FCDI) for water treatment. For energy storage, the flowable electrode is a potential technology that can address the need for large-scale, high-rate storage at the grid scale. However, one fundamental issue important for the electrochemical performance of these systems is the dynamically varying conducting network of moving carbon particles that may result in the underutilization of the slurry material. To address this issue, this research project has clarified various electrochemical effects of hydrodynamic behaviors inside slurry electrodes through computational modeling and experimental efforts.

First, a computational multiphysics model was developed to simulate the particles' hydrodynamic interactions, their random movement, and the resulting dynamic electrical network in which the particles act like individual capacitors with on-and-off connections. This model was used to simulate the unique charging process of the slurry and to study how the system conditions such as slurry concentration, flow speed, and conductive additives (e.g., carbon black) affect the charging performance of the slurry.

The experimental study features a novel platform of miniaturized microfluidic electrochemical flow capacitor, or MEFC, to investigate the hydrodynamic effect of the slurry. Previously, experimental studies on EFCs were not able to provide much insight of the particle behavior in the slurry at flow conditions given the opaque device and carbon slurry, which greatly limits understanding of how the particle dynamics affects the system performance. The new platform made of transparent materials allows for direct observation of the particle interactions in the slurry under an optical microscope and simultaneous measurements of the electrochemical performance of the slurry.

This study revealed two competing effects on the slurry's charging/discharging performance when the flow rate is varied. Specifically, at lower flow rates, particle clusters are more spread across the flow channel between the two stationary electrodes with increased chances of contact between the particles and the stationary electrode for charge transfer, but the number of particle-particle interactions is low, which limits the spread of the charge throughout the slurry. At higher flow rates the number of particle interactions increases dramatically, but the particles tend to move toward the channel centerline where the shear is lowest, which reduces the particle interactions with the stationary electrode. These observations were verified by a non-monotonic trend in the electrochemical data, which showed that a middle flow rate corresponds to the best electrochemical performance.

In a follow-up experiment with the MEFC, three-dimensional (3D) gold electrodes were integrated into the flow channels to better visualize the particle interactions with a stationary electrode. Several rectangular gold micropillars were included in the flow channel using electroplating, which function as the extruded 3D electrode into the slurry. The particle interactions with these microelectrodes of different lengths in the flow direction were examined under microscope, which revealed distinct interactions with the sidewall of the microelectrodes as the electrode length increases. Overall, the 3D gold electrodes result in an enhanced interactions between the particle cluster and the stationary electrodes, which leads to a great increase by three times in the charging/discharging current, thus significantly improving the performance of the slurry electrode. 

In summary, this project has resulted in novel computational models and experimental apparatuses for the fundamental studies of the flowable electrode and has significantly improved our understanding of the underlying mechanism in the EFC.

 


Last Modified: 04/14/2024
Modified by: Haoxiang Luo

Image
  • A schematic of the miniaturized electrochemical flow capacitor (MEFC) that was made using transparent materials, allowing for direct observation of the carbon slurry flow under a microscope/camera as well as for simultaneous charging/discharging measurements.

    A miniaturized electrochemical flow capacitor
